sub_title: R&D Process Engineer at Cano-ela | MSc. Eng. Food Technology | Process Engineering - Innovation Management - Data Analysis
summary:
Bachelor of Food Engineering. I am an analytical person with more than five (05) years of working on creating opportunities to boost innovation through triple helix innovation projects; and leading R&D projects in the design and development of new food products and ingredients involving extraction, fermentation, and drying technologies putting into value bioactive compounds, polymers, hydrocolloids, and dyes obtained from waste reuse, on lab and pilot scale. As a result, three (03) marketable products, five (05) publications, and 600K EUR fundraised for the Grupo ITEPA-PUCP.

My next step was to specialize in food engineering and innovation at the best agri-food university in the world. For that purpose, I was awarded a full scholarship for a master’s degree in Food Technology at Wageningen University by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands. There I honed my skills in product design, sustainable process engineering, and innovation management. 

That rewarding experience made me aware of the need for the food industry to match the technology revolution that we are having nowadays. For that reason, I decided to be skillful in statistical analysis with no-code and coding software, and thus see opportunities that help them connect.

I am passionate about meeting and connecting with people from all over the world, and my goal is to continue working on the creating opportunities to encourage innovation through the development of products and ingredients from waste reuse and/or with less waste. This is where I can create a lot of value. 

I am also interested in being part of the food transition in the valorization of sustainable plant-based alternative sources by understanding how innovations in novel technologies such as ICT and additive manufacturing can enhance our agri-food system toward a sustainable future.

projects.title: Exploitation of Peruvian wine industry waste by obtaining bioactive compounds and its addition in biofunctional products formulation.
projects.description: An efficient process will be developed through the use of clean physicochemical and biotechnological technologies for the use of waste from the wine industry. From this process, high value-added products such as polyphenolic extracts and oils with a high content of tocopherol and unsaturated fatty acids will be obtained, in order to be added into functional products.

contributors.headline: R&D Process Engineer at Cano-ela | MSc. Eng. Food Technology | Process Engineering - Innovation Management - Data Analysis

projects.title: Evaluation of total carotenoids stability in snacks of Lucuma (Pouteria lucuma) dehydrated by hot-air drying
projects.description:
Bachelor Thesis.
Lucuma (Pouteria lucuma), is a fruit that is popular in the diet in Peru with a high content of carotenoids. The aim of this research was to obtain lucuma snacks with a high content of total carotenoids (TCC). The lucuma was processed on a laboratory scale to obtain snacks by convective drying, obtaining a yield of 71.12% average.  The obtained pulp was mixed with additives in different amounts following a mixture design simple-centroid of 3 components, composed by maltodextrin (MD), ascorbic acid (AA) and silicon dioxide (SD); and then kneaded in order to obtain a homogeneous dough. Obtained samples were dried to obtain the texture of a snack using convective drying at two levels of process variable of 50°C and 70°C to determine the best additives mixture and temperature according to the highest TCC remained after convective drying. Results of the mixture samples were also compared with a sample without additives that was dried and another that was lyophilized. From the total of 20 mixtures of additives, each one at two levels of temperature, the TCC was quantified in all samples following a spectrophotometric method. Results showed that the mixture formed by 0% MD, 100% AA and 0% SD with a temperature of 50 °C were the best parameters,  obtaining a TCC of 0.2753 ± 0.031 mg β-carotene/g DM.

projects.title: Development of an optimal process to obtain a spray-dried mucilage of Sanky (Corryocactus brevistylus) and its application as an additive in food processing.
projects.description: The aim of the research was to design an industrial process to obtain sanky mucilage by spray-drying. The obtained product based on its rheological properties was developed in order to be used as a food additive.
